title: Overall
stimulusHtml:
(9 points)

Students are prompted to discuss any three of the four sets of factors, with a total of 3 points maximum available for each of these three factors.

Some students may mix their responses to one part of the question with the other parts (for example, they may discuss social trends in the context of a discussion of landscape preferences). In these cases, student responses should get credit for their discussions, even if they are in a different section of the question.

The maximum of 3 points for each part of the question is awarded as follows:

3 points

A good discussion on two major elements.

2 points

A good discussion of one major element and one other element OR a good discussion of two other elements OR a limited discussion of two major elements.

1 point

Discussion of one major element OR discussion of one other element.

0 points

No major elements or other elements discussed.

Part (a) Transportation

The major elements of transportation that contributed to the acceleration of suburban growth since the 1950's and 1960's included the role of freeways in increasing accessibility to the suburbs for individuals and in opening up large areas of cheap land for the development of low-cost housing, and the role of affordable car transportation. Other transportation elements included the decline of the streetcar system, and a more general multiplier effect that was prompted by transport-driven decentralization of housing and fueled by commercial decentralization.

Part (b) Housing production

The major ways in which housing production enhanced suburbanization included a set of cost savings achieved by new forms of organization of production (for example, the large size of developers, ability to purchase large tracts of land, economies of scale, organization of labor into teams, use of subcontracting); the growing affordability of housing due to the use of new methods (for example, prefabrication, on-site assembly, speed of production, new materials); the growing accessibility of such housing due to improved access to finance (for example, government-backed mortgages) and a streamlined purchase system. Other elements included the existence of tax codes that favored construction of new buildings rather than rehabilitation of old buildings (and loan programs that favored new construction rather than repairs/upgrades).

Part (c) Landscape preferences

There are a wide range of landscape preferences that supported suburbanization. These include a growing anti-big-city feeling with young adults wanting to escape the high density built environment with its associated signifiers of pollution and congestion in favor of a rural idyll; the desire for a large home size with the ranch style design as indicative of the underlying expansionist mood; the desire for single family housing (not tenements); the depiction of suburbs in popular culture as extolling "the American way." Another element also includes a desire for an ethnically homogenous and conformist landscape.

Part (d) Social and demographic trends

Major elements include the way that the baby boom provided demographic demand for housing expansion; the market for providing housing to accommodate nuclear (not extended) families; the changing social construction of the family and the ideology of the nuclear family as a mode family; the gender division of labor and the placing of women in suburbs (cult of domesticity). Other elements include white flight and, more generally, the desire of ethnic/race groups to flock together; the growing importance of children's education as a middle class value and the view that suburbs could provide a better product.

Some students may mix their responses to one part of the question with the other parts (for example, they may discuss social trends in the context of a discussion of landscape preferences). Part (a) Transportation

The major elements of transportation that contributed to the acceleration of suburban growth since the 1950's and 1960's included the role of freeways in increasing accessibility to the suburbs for individuals and in opening up large areas of cheap land for the development of low-cost housing, and the role of affordable car transportation. Other transportation elements included the decline of the streetcar system, and a more general multiplier effect that was prompted by transport-driven decentralization of housing and fueled by commercial decentralization.

Part (b) Housing production

Other elements included the existence of tax codes that favored construction of new buildings rather than rehabilitation of old buildings (and loan programs that favored new construction rather than repairs/upgrades).

Part (c) Landscape preferences

There are a wide range of landscape preferences that supported suburbanization. These include a growing anti-big-city feeling with young adults wanting to escape the high density built environment with its associated signifiers of pollution and congestion in favor of a rural idyll; the desire for a large home size with the ranch style design as indicative of the underlying expansionist mood; the desire for single family housing (not tenements); the depiction of suburbs in popular culture as extolling "the American way." Another element also includes a desire for an ethnically homogenous and conformist landscape.

Part (d) Social and demographic trends

Major elements include the way that the baby boom provided demographic demand for housing expansion; the market for providing housing to accommodate nuclear (not extended) families; the changing social construction of the family and the ideology of the nuclear family as a mode family; the gender division of labor and the placing of women in suburbs (cult of domesticity). Other elements include white flight and, more generally, the desire of ethnic/race groups to flock together; the growing importance of children's education as a middle class value and the view that suburbs could provide a better product.
